channel.title: Anti-tax dodging protestors hit central London
channel.description:
This is an totally original story. I've just come back from protests.
A plutocrat called Philip Green runs some of the biggest retail stores in the country, his empire includes Topshop, Topman, Dorothy Perkins, Burton, Miss Selfridge and British Home Stores. Yet, Philip Green employs an army of accountants to help him dodge tax. In recent years this has cost the British taxpayer £295 million. To put this into perspective, it could pay for the salaries of 20,000 NHS nurses.
[img]http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2010/12/18/article-1339844-0C5B5F8B000005DC-248_468x371.jpg[/img]
So we hit him where it hurts, in his pocket. We had a sit-in in the flagshop Topshop store in Oxford Street. We closed it down to business on that busy Saturday and handed out leaflets to damage their reputation and encourage our rulers to close the tax loopholes.
Vodafone dodged £6 billion worth of tax. To put this into perspective, cuts of welfare are valued at £7 billion. So we did the same, sit-ins at the Oxford Street Vodafone store.
[img]http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2010/12/18/article-1339844-0C873C54000005DC-124_468x316.jpg[/img]
Our government tells us lies that There Is No Alternative and We're All In This Together. They destroy out welfare state while allowing rich oligarchs to pay little or no tax. We believe everyone should pay their fair share of tax.
Even the Chancellor George Osborne is a tax dodger. The company he inherited from his dad pays accountants to make him avoid £1.6 million worth of tax. 23 of the 29 members of our government's cabinet are millionaires. How can they possibly understand the normal man or woman on the street?
Join us. http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/
Our American friends also have a group. http://www.usuncut.org/ I understand they occupy Bank Of America and Verizon because they pay zero ($0) tax.

item.title: Anti-tax dodging protestors hit central London
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:51, topic:388153”]What? No…

The companies have been used to the bush tax cuts for a decade now, as the recession got worse it started to become a bad idea if we brought the taxes back up again because it could cause layoffs and that would only make the problem worse.[/quote]

There’s no need to bring taxes up, there’s a need to enforce tax laws. Basic government finance: Taxes come in, expenses go out. Differences between the two are dealt with via the financial markets. The US knows how to use these markets!

You should read this article Frell: http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/25/business/economy/25tax.html?_r=1&scp=2&sq=ge&st=cse

Please understand this: We (the European members of this forum) aren’t always right either, and I for one sometimes like to argue with you just for the sake of arguing. But also understand that you’re being fed lies. I don’t know who it’s doing, but someone is.

Read full topic
item.source: Anti-tax dodging protestors hit central London

item.title: Anti-tax dodging protestors hit central London
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

What? No…

The companies have been used to the bush tax cuts for a decade now, as the recession got worse it started to become a bad idea if we brought the taxes back up again because it could cause layoffs and that would only make the problem worse.

You guys are so quick to think that as soon as a company gets tax cuts the CEO’s are going to give themselves raises and just pocket the extra profit. What actually happens is the money goes to Health insurance for employees, retirement programs for employees, shareholders, reinvesting into the company, and research and development.

Of course, you guys don’t have to worry about the first two, so the extra money can go to the government so it can provide those things.

yakman:

Don’t tax the big guys and maybe they’ll throw us a few crumbs from the high table in the form of shitty minimum wage jobs.

So what? Throw out some minimum wage jobs and help the starting generation of workers. That allows more pay/positions for management that goes to the people who are actually applying themselves and have a career with the company.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Actually small business taxes are usually pushed to be lower than bigger ones. But right now isn’t a great time for small business so we had to cut taxes for empires to keep from anymore layoffs.

item.title: Anti-tax dodging protestors hit central London
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:47, topic:388153”]we’re well aware. GM hasn’t paid either.

Our government isn’t buckling down on them because they’re the only hope for jobs right now.[/quote]

What is GM going to do? Move all it’s production lines to Mexico? If Americans are so proud of their own car brands, would they take it when GM does that? I doubt it. American car brands stay alive because of the ‘made in the USA’ tag.

Besides, this basically is saying to the small business ‘you either grow or pay taxes’. Not every businessman wants to grow into a huge corporation. The day there are only huge corporations left (ie a plutocracy) I’ll retire to a cave.

Read full topic

item.title: Anti-tax dodging protestors hit central London
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

[size=10pt]2/3 of American Corporations Pay No Federal Taxes[/size]

Bank of America hasn’t paid a nickel in federal income taxes for the past two years, and in fact raked in an additional $1 billion in tax “benefits.” The bank is enjoying these profits after accepting $45 billion from taxpayers, which the company then got to count as a deduction when they paid back the money. [..] This is why two-thirds of corporations in America pay no federal income taxes. If they were forced to, we're told, the whole country would suffer. Jobs would be lost, salaries slashed. Thank heavens we’ve avoided such calamity by allowing corporations to shape legislation in their favor.

In 2010, Bank of America handed out $2.2 million in campaign contributions to Congressional representatives and PACs (36 percent went to Democrats, 64 percent to Republicans). By throwing around that much cash, huge companies like BoA have a big say when it comes to crafting legislation that permits them to escape paying taxes, according to US Uncut organizer J.A. Myerson.

Alternet – 3 Feb 18

2/3rds of US Corporations Pay Zero Federal Taxes: US Uncut Movement Builds to...

From coast-to-coast, more than forty cities joined in a day of action protesting the tax-dodging of massive corporations that they see as the real source of the country's deficit. The following article first appeared on the Nation.com. For more great...

Read full topic

item.title: Anti-tax dodging protestors hit central London
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Saphire`, post:38, topic:388153”]Err, it’s the way things are at the moment though. With all the prices on everything raising I’m finding it pretty hard to survive.

Guess that’s what mortgages does, brilliant home, can’t pay :/[/quote]

You don’t have any savings? If not, then I partially agree with mwiebelhaus. This crisis is caused by a bubble in the housing market, and I won’t put all the blame on banks. People seem to forget that banks want to make profit too, and just like car dealers they don’t always tell the complete truth.

Read full topic

item.title: Anti-tax dodging protestors hit central London
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

I unfortunately couldn’t attend the riots on saturday however I was around yesterday and I was laughing so hard as I walked past endless graffiti and the desperate attempts to fix up everything

To be honest, It’s still hard to believe that there is a loophole like this and nothing has been done about it for a very long time. Tax is a tax and it does not matter whether you are the Average Bob or a successful entrepreneur, it still should be paid!

needs moar communism…

Read full topic

item.title: Anti-tax dodging protestors hit central London
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:28, topic:388153”][quote author=Frell link=topic=483969.msg3546939#msg3546939 date=1301247584]
We also have the second highest corporal tax rate in the world under this administration.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_companies_by_revenue I see a good bit of american flags on that list (3 in the top 10). Im not saying there arent any successful European companies.

You also have to realize that most of these foreign companies make as much money as they do because they outsource to the US. And surprisingly, US companies outsource over seas as we jack up taxes trying to “fix” our debt.
[/quote]

Dunno how you’re reading that list, but theres 2 in the top 10 not 3[/quote]
well when i load it the rank number 16 is positioned between 7 and 8 for some reason (it does say 16 however) he clearly just saw that and assumed it was in the top 10

Read full topic
